newsitem.title: POLAND: MORE POLES HEAD SOUTH TO CZECH REPUBLIC, SLOVAKIA.
newsitem.headline: MORE POLES HEAD SOUTH TO CZECH REPUBLIC, SLOVAKIA.

text.p: People are crossing Poland's southern border with the Czech Republic and Slovakia a third more often than a year ago, with Poles heading south 42 percent more frequently, the Central Statistical Office (GUS) said.
Though more than half of Polish border-crossers in the first six months this year traversed the country's western frontier with Germany, they did so less often than in 1995.
In the January-June period people crossed the Polish-German border some 58 million times, down from 63 million times in the first half of last year, GUS said.

Overall, people crossed Polish borders some 112 million times in the first half of this year, or 5.5 percent more often than during the same period last year, with Polish citizens making up 32.4 percent of the international traffic.

Poland's southern border was crossed a third more often, nearly 39 million times, and the country's eastern and northern borders, which include Ukraine, Belarus, Lithuania and Russia's Kaliningrad enclave, was crossed 13 million times, eight percent more often than last year, GUS said.
GUS said foreigners in Poland bought 5.23 billion zlotys worth of goods in Poland during the first six months of the year, up some 27 percent from January-June 1995.
